Award.AwardTitle: Slowing, Cooling, and Spectroscopy with Stimulated Optical Forces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Under normal conditions, molecules in the air move at speeds of nearly 500 meters per second, and if they were not constantly bumping into one another, they would travel an inch in just 50 millionths of a second. This grant will support research on new methods for using lasers to bring atoms or molecules to a standstill within this same one-inch range, by producing decelerations a million times the force of gravity. For the case of atoms, the objective is to improve upon existing methods, by greatly increasing the force and the velocity range over which the force is usable. For molecules, it has proven to be extremely difficult to apply standard methods, owing to the relative complexity of the internal quantum structure of molecules. Thus a particular emphasis will be placed on effective schemes for decelerating and cooling molecules, using as a test system the calcium monofluoride molecule, CaF. Optimal approaches will be determined by a combination of numerical modeling and experimental tests using laser beams that contain light at multiple colors simultaneously. The resulting cold atoms and molecules will be investigated using lasers to probe their internal energy structure. The apparatus will also be used to study the interaction of molecules with each other under unusual conditions. There are possible applications to chemical physics, cold plasma formation, electric field calibration, and quantum computation. The project will help train and educate undergraduate and graduate students.

The proposed research addresses three main motivations: to develop and understand the physics of stimulated optical forces, to achieve large improvements in direct laser slowing and cooling of atomic and molecular beams, and to investigate excited-state structure and dynamics in atomic He and molecular CaF. Helium and CaF are chosen partially for their fundamental interest, and partially because they are excellent candidates for manipulation by stimulated optical forces. The stimulated bichromatic force (BCF) and the newly-proposed polychromatic force (PCF) are rectified coherent optical forces from multi-frequency laser beams that can be hundreds of times stronger than the conventional radiative force. As part of the proposed research, a prototype chirped-BCF decelerator for He will be completed, and a promising new four-color PCF version will be tested and compared with calculations. A similar decelerator will be developed for the CaF molecule, a species that has attracted considerable recent interest as a candidate for direct laser slowing and cooling. For molecules, there is an additional advantage to utilizing coherent optical forces beyond merely increasing the force. Because hundreds of BCF momentum exchanges can occur for each radiative decay event, the BCF can reduce the velocity by hundreds of times more than incoherent radiative forces before the molecule decays into an inaccessible "dark" state. Several spectroscopic experiments will be initiated on the resulting cold atoms and molecules, including studies of cold gases of highly-excited Rydberg states of CaF, and precise laser spectroscopy of both He and CaF. The study of cold molecules in Rydberg states is a little-explored topic likely to involve new physical phenomena. Precise spectroscopy of helium will facilitate tests of basic theory and pave the way for future ultra-precise measurements. Novel applications of metastable helium beams will also be explored.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated a new type of radiative force on molecules. Laser light has been used to exert forces on atoms for a number of years. The resulting laser cooling and trapping has allowed the preparation of ultracold (<1 mK) samples of atoms at high densities for use in improved atomic clocks, atom interferometers for precise gravity measurements, Bose-Einstein condensation, quantum computation, collisions at ultralow temperatures, and other applications. More recently, these techniques have been extended to simple molecules. This extension is not trivial because in addition to having their electrons excited, molecules can vibrate and rotate. These additional degrees of freedom result in molecules having many more energy levels than atoms. Keeping the molecules in the relevant quantum states is thus more difficult, making radiative forces less effective. The radiation pressure force has been successfully used to cool and trap molecules, but its maximum value is limited by how fast the molecule can scatter photons in the laser excitation process. Also, this photon scattering, which involves spontaneous decay of the excited state, can transfer the molecule into undesirable states, effectively turning off the force. In this project, a novel force which does not rely on spontaneous decay, the bichromatic force, was investigated both experimentally and theoretically. This force can be much larger than ordinary radiation pressure, and because it does not rely on spontaneous decay, is particular well suited to molecular systems with their numerous energy levels.

In the simulations, we calculated the force exerted on molecules by a bichromatic standing wave laser field consisting of two frequencies symmetrically tuned above and below a molecular resonance. These calculations included the multiple relevant energy levels, as well as their magnetic sublevels, of the molecule. The force was calculated as a function of molecular velocity, laser intensity, and relative phase between the two counterpropagating beams of the standing wave, in order to compare with the experimental measurements, and to guide future experiments. Results of the simulations and the experiment agreed rather well.

In the experiment, a pulsed supersonic beam of CaF molecules was sent through a bichromatic (two-color) standing-wave laser field. The resulting force on the molecules was measured via the transvese deflection of the beam. This deflection was determined by monitoring the number of molecules passing through a slit scanned transverse to the beam. The molecules were detected by their fluorescence upon illumination by a separate laser. We achieved a bichromatic force approximately four times the maximum radiation pressure force. If this bichromatic force were used to decelerate a molecular beam, the stopping distance would be approximately one fourth that required for the maximum achievable radiation pressure force, meaning that the number of cold molecules available for capture in a trap would be larger by a factor of approximately sixteen. This would be a great benefit to future experiments.

In this project, we have also developed micro-controller based devices for use in controlling various aspects of the experiment and measuring a variety of signals. Examples include lock-in amplifiers, diode laser current controllers, and modulators for rf. These devices should prove useful in a wide range of research projects and advanced teaching labs, providing high performance and flexibility at low cost. Designs and instructions have been made publicly available.
